PHASE 1

DISCOVERING PLACES

Moving to next section.

A. Holiday Places (1/2)

Look at Section A on your worksheet. Circle any words you don't know yet!

camp site a place where you can pitch a tent or park a caravan
self-catering flat flat which you rent, you cook for yourself
guesthouse accommodation like a hotel but cheaper and with fewer services

A. Holiday Places (2/2)

youth hostel cheap accommodation, mainly for young people, with, perhaps, ten or more people sleeping in bunk beds in one room
holiday camp a place providing holiday accommodation in little chalets or flats, with facilities and entertainment
time-share apartment accommodation which one owns a part of and has the right to stay there for 2 weeks every year

DISCUSSION

CHALLENGING PLACES

Youth Hostel

Cheap, social, but shared. You might sleep in a room with 10+ strangers!

Time-share

Luxury owning. You own 1/26th of the flat and stay 2 weeks every year.

Which one would you choose? Why?

Discuss preferences. Focus on the concept of 'shared' vs 'owned' to help students differentiate.

B. Holiday Activities

Which of these have you done? Tick them on your worksheet!

Primary Activity Variations / Alternative Forms
sunbathe swim / go swimming
do sightseeing go sightseeing
ski go skiing / go for a drive
hike go hiking / tour / go touring
go on an excursion -
climb go climbing / camp / go camping
Elicit the 'go + -ing' pattern. Check meaning of 'excursion'.

TIPS

B. THE RULE (Meaning)

'Been' vs 'Gone' (Meaning)

BEEN: Finished experiences. You went there and you came back.

"I have been to Paris." (I am here now)

GONE: Unfinished actions. You went there and you are still there.

"He has gone to Paris." (He is in Paris now)
Discuss the strategy with students.

TIPS

B. THE RULE (Form)

'Been' vs 'Gone' (Form)

Use Present Perfect (Have/Has + Past Participle):

  • Have you ever been skiing?
  • He has gone skiing.

Ask your partner about their holiday experiences!

Discuss the strategy with students.

C. Useful Hotel Language (1/2)

Find Section C. Which phrase is the most useful for you?

I'd like to book a single/double room with a cot.
I'd like a room with a shower, a colour TV, and a view of the sea.
What time do you serve breakfast?
Am I too late for dinner/to get something to eat?
Is service included?
Could I have a call at 7.30, please?

C. Useful Hotel Language (2/2)

Could we have dinner in our room, please?
The teasmade in my room isn't working.
I'd like an extra pillow, please.
I'd like to make a call to New Zealand, please.
What time do you like rooms to be vacated by?
Sorry to bother you, but...
I'm afraid there's something wrong with the...

GRAMMAR

TASK 3: VERB TRANSFORMATIONS

  1. They went canoeing in the Dordogne last year.
  2. Have you ever been windsurfing?
  3. I love going sailing.
  4. He spends too much time fishing.
Monitor student progress.

KEY

TASK 3: THE ANSWERS

  1. They canoed in the Dordogne last year.
    Logic: Change the phrase 'go + ing' to the past simple verb.
  2. Have you ever windsurfed?
    Logic: Use the verb 'windsurf' as a past participle.
  3. I love sailing.
    Logic: You can use the gerund 'sailing' directly without 'going'.
  4. He fishes too much.
    Logic: Transform 'spend time + ing' into the main verb + 'too much'.
Monitor student progress.

ACCURACY

TASK 4: SPOT THE MISTAKES

The Smiths stayed at a camping last summer because all other holiday accommodations are too expensive.

Mrs Smith had a sunbath, Mr Smith made a sight-seeing and the children made a travel. One day they made an excursion.

Monitor student progress.

FIXED

TASK 4: THE WHY?

The Smiths stayed at a campsite last summer because all other holiday accommodation are too expensive.

Mrs Smith sunbathed, Mr Smith went sightseeing and the children went for a tour. One day they went on an excursion.

Monitor student progress.
